entry.title: The Occupational Pension Schemes (Validation of Rule Alterations) Regulations 1998
The West of Scotland Water Authority (Loch Lossit, Islay) (Amendment) Water Order 1998
The Amusement Machine Licence Duty (Monetary Amounts) Order 1998
The Education (School Performance Information) (Wales) Regulations 1998

category.term: Special educational needs and additional support

entry.summary: These Regulations, which relate to the provision to the Secretary of State and to parents of information about the performance of schools and other specified information, apply in relation to schools and local education authorities in Wales. They replace, with some changes, the Education (School Performance Information) (Wales) Regulations 1997, which are revoked. The main changes are summarised below.

entry.title: The Magistrates' Courts (Procedure) Act 1998 (Commencement No. 1) Order 1998
The Merchant Shipping (Code of Safe Working Practices for Merchant Seamen) Regulations 1998
entry.summary: These Regulations, which revoke and replace The Merchant Shipping (Code of Safe Working Practices) Regulations 1980 (S.I. 1980/686), require the owner (or other person assuming responsibility for ownership) of each UK ship, other than fishing vessels or pleasure vessels, to carry on board and make available to workers “The Code of Safe Working Practices for Merchant Seamen” (published in 1998 and obtainable from The Stationery Office) (“the Code”).

entry.title: The Private Water Supplies (Scotland) Amendment Regulations 1998
entry.summary: These Regulations amend the Private Water Supplies (Scotland) Regulations 1992 (“the principal Regulations”). Regulation 3(b) amends the principal Regulations so that they do not apply to a private supply used for the mashing process or for washing plant during the distillation of spirits. Regulation 4 introduces new charging provisions for councils. Regulation 5 allows councils to arrange for persons other than “relevant persons” in terms of the principal Regulations to take samples, as well as analyse them, and requires councils to be satisfied that those taking and analysing samples are competent to do so. Regulations 6 and 7 provide for reduced sampling frequencies for certain supplies when the premises served by those supplies are used for less than six months in any year. Regulation 8 amends the principal Regulations to take account of local government reorganisation.

entry.title: Plastic Materials and Articles in Contact with Food Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1998
entry.summary: These Regulations come into operation on 14th September 1998.

entry.title: The Pneumoconiosis etc. (Workers’ Compensation) (Payment of Claims) Amendment Regulations 1998

ukm:Supersedes.dc:title: The Pneumoconiosis etc. (Workers' Compensation) (Payment of Claims) Amendment Regulations 1998

entry.summary: Under the Pneumoconiosis etc. (Workers’ Compensation) Act 1979 (“the Act”) lump sum payments may be made to certain persons disabled by a disease to which the Act applies, or to dependants of persons who were so disabled immediately before they died.

entry.title: The Education (Student Loans) (Amendment) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1998
entry.summary: The Education (Student Loans) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1998 (“the principal Regulations”) govern student loans made under the Education (Student Loans) (Northern Ireland) Order 1990, which are mortgage style repayment loans. It is the intention that after 1st September 1998 such loans will be made primarily to students who started their courses before that date, and certain other students. New style loans repayable through the tax system will be made to students starting courses after that date.

entry.title: The A205 Trunk Road (Lewisham) Red Route Traffic Order 1998
The Fossil Fuel Levy (Amendment) Regulations 1998
Coventry Airport (Designation) (Detention and Sale of Aircraft) Order 1998
The Environment Agency (Transfer of Functions of the Swavesey Internal Drainage Board) Order 1998
The Houses in Multiple Occupation (Fees for Registration Schemes) (Amendment) Order 1998
The Education (Individual Performance Information) (Identification of Individual Pupils) Regulations 1998
The Houses in Multiple Occupation (Charges for Registration Schemes) Regulations 1998
The Local Authorities (Direct Labour Organisations) (Competition) (Insolvency) (Amendment) (Wales) Regulations 1998
entry.summary: Regulation 2 of these Regulations amends the Local Authorities (Direct Labour Organisations) (Competition) (Wales) Regulations 1997 so that local authorities in Wales are exempt from the competitive tendering requirements of Part III of the Local Government, Planning and Land Act 1980 in respect of certain functional work. The functional work is that which consists of a job the whole or part of which the authority is undertaking because a contractor has been, but, by reason of falling within regulation 10B(3) as inserted by these Regulations, is no longer undertaking for that authority, and the authority will be undertaking the work for no more than 12 months from the day on which the contractor ceased to undertake the work in question.

entry.title: The Education (School Inspection) (Wales) Regulations 1998
entry.summary: These Regulations consolidate, with amendments, the Education (School Inspection) (Wales) (No. 2) Regulations 1993, as amended by the Education (School Inspection) (Wales) (No. 2) (Amendment) Regulations 1993, the Education (School Inspection) (Wales) (No. 2) (Amendment) Regulations 1996 and the Education (School Inspection) (Wales) (No. 2) (Amendment) Regulations 1997.

entry.title: The Children (1995 Order) (Amendment) (Children’s Services Planning) Order (Northern Ireland) 1998
entry.summary: This Order inserts a new paragraph in Schedule 2 to the Children (Northern Ireland) Order 1995, which requires every Health and Social Services Board to prepare and publish plans for the provision of children’s services within its area and to keep those plans under review. In preparing or updating its plans, a Health and Social Services Board is required to consult Health and Social Services trusts, education and library boards, district councils, certain voluntary organisations, the Northern Ireland Housing Executive, the Probation Board for Northern Ireland, the police and other relevant bodies. The Department of Health and Social Services may require a Health and Social Services Board’s plan to be submitted to it at any time.
